values.description:
This PR is an attempt to port the plugin features of `ign-common` into its own project with its own library name while roughly maintaining the version history.

This PR is probably unwieldy, but it's mostly just a restructuring and renaming of all the plugin code that's currently in `ign-common`'s default branch.
values.title: Part 2: port PluginPtrSemantics to new repository

summary.raw:
This PR is an attempt to port the plugin features of `ign-common` into its own project with its own library name while roughly maintaining the version history.

This PR is probably unwieldy, but it's mostly just a restructuring and renaming of all the plugin code that's currently in `ign-common`'s default branch.
summary.html:
This PR is an attempt to port the plugin features of ign-common into its own project with its own library name while roughly maintaining the version history.

This PR is probably unwieldy, but it's mostly just a restructuring and renaming of all the plugin code that's currently in ign-common's default branch.

values.description:
This PR introduces some enormous improvements to registering and managing plugins.

1. Now users can register template-based classes as plugins and/or interfaces.
2. Plugin libraries that are no longer in use will be automatically unloaded.
3. A plugin can be registered anywhere from within any translation unit.
4. Interfaces never need to be queried by name with a string.

\(1\) is of particular importance to `ign-physics`, which inexorably requires this feature.
values.title: Part 3: Better plugin registration and management

summary.raw:
This PR introduces some enormous improvements to registering and managing plugins.

1. Now users can register template-based classes as plugins and/or interfaces.
2. Plugin libraries that are no longer in use will be automatically unloaded.
3. A plugin can be registered anywhere from within any translation unit.
4. Interfaces never need to be queried by name with a string.

\(1\) is of particular importance to `ign-physics`, which inexorably requires this feature.
summary.html:
This PR introduces some enormous improvements to registering and managing plugins.

  1. Now users can register template-based classes as plugins and/or interfaces.
  2. Plugin libraries that are no longer in use will be automatically unloaded.
  3. A plugin can be registered anywhere from within any translation unit.
  4. Interfaces never need to be queried by name with a string.

(1) is of particular importance to ign-physics, which inexorably requires this feature.

values.description:
This was split out from pull request #1 to make its diff easier to read.

Most of this is just moving the gtest folder from `core/test/gtest` to `test/gtest` (03b02f5 and 6781e4d). There are minor changes from pull request #1 that I ported over in 1c17951, 4fcfe56, and 97eaae2 that allow cmake to configure, but it fails due to issues with the loader. So I view this a success if cmake configures correctly with this branch and pull request #1 is able to build correctly with a more readable diff.

values.description:
[![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_plugin-ci-default-bionic-amd64&build=5)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_plugin-ci-default-bionic-amd64/5/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_plugin-ci-default-bionic-amd64/5/cppcheckResult/

The error is: "Skipping configuration 'RTLD_NOLOAD' since the value of 'RTLD_NOLOAD' is unknown. Use -D if you want to check it. You can use -U to skip it explicitly." So I've enabled it with `-DRTLD_NOLOAD`.

I also removed some irrelevant `-U` flags copied from ign-common and added the register component to code_check.sh.

I also removed some irrelevant -U flags copied from ign-common and added the register component to code_check.sh.

values.title: Avoid repeating any direct base classes for ComposePlugin

summary.html:
If a user requests a specialized plugin like

using MySpecPluginPtr = ignition::plugin::SpecializedPluginPtr<Foo, Foo>;

it can produce a compilation error because C++ is not okay with direct double-inheritance, like

class Bar : public Foo, public Foo { };

This PR uses a template specialization to avoid this compilation error.

Note that while it would be silly for a user to intentionally request a repeated specialized interface, it can happen very easily during template metaprogramming, which is something that we want to have robust support for, because of ign-physics.

values.description: Similar to Pull Request #7, it wouldn’t make sense for a user to intentionally use this directly, but it’s useful for template metaprograms, because otherwise consumer template metaprograms need to explicitly handle the special case where they have no interfaces to specialize for.
values.title: Allow empty Plugin specializations

summary.raw: Similar to Pull Request #7, it wouldn’t make sense for a user to intentionally use this directly, but it’s useful for template metaprograms, because otherwise consumer template metaprograms need to explicitly handle the special case where they have no interfaces to specialize for.

values.description:
This PR adds a `WeakPluginPtr` class that allows us to track the life of a Plugin without keeping its reference up.

That allows us to also create an `EnablePluginFromThis` interface for plugins, analogous to `std::enable_shared_from_this`. The `EnablePluginFromThis` class will allow us to create “factory” plugins in a future PR.
values.title: Plugin Enhancements Part 1: EnablePluginFromThis

summary.raw:
This PR adds a `WeakPluginPtr` class that allows us to track the life of a Plugin without keeping its reference up.

That allows us to also create an `EnablePluginFromThis` interface for plugins, analogous to `std::enable_shared_from_this`. The `EnablePluginFromThis` class will allow us to create “factory” plugins in a future PR.
summary.html:
This PR adds a WeakPluginPtr class that allows us to track the life of a Plugin without keeping its reference up.

That allows us to also create an EnablePluginFromThis interface for plugins, analogous to std::enable_shared_from_this. The EnablePluginFromThis class will allow us to create “factory” plugins in a future PR.

values.description:
This PR implements the concept of plugin “aliases”. An “alias” is an alternative name for a plugin that can be used to instantiate it, as long as the alias does not conflict with any other plugin names or plugin aliases.

The aliasing ability is helpful for allowing plugins to have clean user-friendly names. This is especially important when a plugin is implemented through a template, which may have an excessively complicated symbol name by default.
values.title: Plugin Enhancements Part 2: Aliases

summary.raw:
This PR implements the concept of plugin “aliases”. An “alias” is an alternative name for a plugin that can be used to instantiate it, as long as the alias does not conflict with any other plugin names or plugin aliases.

The aliasing ability is helpful for allowing plugins to have clean user-friendly names. This is especially important when a plugin is implemented through a template, which may have an excessively complicated symbol name by default.
summary.html:
This PR implements the concept of plugin “aliases”. An “alias” is an alternative name for a plugin that can be used to instantiate it, as long as the alias does not conflict with any other plugin names or plugin aliases.

The aliasing ability is helpful for allowing plugins to have clean user-friendly names. This is especially important when a plugin is implemented through a template, which may have an excessively complicated symbol name by default.

values.title: Plugin Enhancements Part 3: Factory

summary.html:
This PR is the last in the line of the new enhancements to plugins.

A common requirement for plugin classes is that it needs to be possible to hand off ownership of the object that has been imported from the external library. For example, if you want to have a QWidget plugin, you need to pass a raw pointer of that QWidget off to a native Qt parent object which will then manage its lifecycle.

This creates some friction with our plugin framework, because we need to track the usage of each shared library to make sure that we don't unload a library while one of its symbols is still in use. @chapulina dodged this in ign-gui by manually keeping a reference-count to the original plugin alive, and then manually deleting the widgets before that reference count gets wiped out.

In this PR, we fix this problem entirely using a "Factory" paradigm. Now you can define a plugin Factory which takes in some number of arguments (or no arguments at all) and produces a std::unique_ptr<Interface> where Interface is the interface you want to give to the plugin consumer. In the case of Qt, you can .release() this pointer and hand it off to a parent widget, which will manage its lifecycle. As long as that Interface object is alive, the plugin framework will keep its library loaded, so there is no need to manually hold onto a reference count or to manually delete objects.

I’ll use ign-gui as an example of how the factory can be used:

// file: ignition/gui/Plugin.hh

#ifndef IGNITION_GUI_PLUGIN_HH_
#define IGNITION_GUI_PLUGIN_HH_

#include <QWidget>
#include <ignition/plugin/Factory.hh>

namespace ignition {
namespace gui {

class IGNITION_GUI_VISIBLE Plugin : public QWidget
{
  // virtual member functions
  // member variables
  // etc
};

// Define a factory that takes no inputs and produces a
// std::unique_ptr<Plugin>
using WidgetFactory = ignition::plugin::Factory<Plugin>;

}
}

#endif

‌

// file: user/src/plugin.cc

#include <ignition/gui/Plugin.hh>
#include <ignition/plugin/Register.hh>

class MyGuiWidget : public ignition::gui::Plugin
{
  // implement virtual functions
  // declare member variables
  // etc
};

IGNITION_ADD_FACTORY(MyGuiWidget, ignition::gui::WidgetFactory)

And then you would retrieve the user's MyGuiWidget plugin by doing the following:

ignition::plugin::Loader loader;
loader.LoadLibrary("/path/to/user/library");

std::unique_ptr<ignition::gui::Plugin> plugin =
    loader.Factory("MyGuiWidget")->Construct();

// Now you can safely pass the widget off to its parent by calling
// plugin.release(). You do not need to manage its reference count from
// here on out.

‌

Note that we can also make factories that accept arguments to pass to the constructor of the plugin object. For example, if we wanted the plugin object constructors to accept the same arguments as the base QWidget class (I'm not saying this is a good idea, I'm just offering a hypothetical):

// file: ignition/gui/Plugin.hh

/* class Plugin definition goes here */

using WidgetFactory = ignition::plugin::Factory<Plugin, QWidget*, Qt::WindowFlags>;

‌

// file: user/src/plugin.cc

#include <ignition/gui/Plugin.hh>
#include <ignition/plugin/Register.hh>

class MyGuiWidget : public ignition::gui::Plugin
{
  public: MyGuiWidget(QWidget* parent, Qt::WindowFlags f);

  // implement virtual functions
  // declare member variables
  // etc
};

IGNITION_ADD_FACTORY(MyGuiWidget, ignition::gui::WidgetFactory)

And then you would construct it like this:

ignition::plugin::Loader loader;
loader.LoadLibrary("/path/to/user/library");

QWidget* parent = getParent();
Qt::WindowFlags flags = getFlags();

std::unique_ptr<ignition::gui::Plugin> plugin =
    loader.Factory("MyGuiWidget")->Construct(parent, flags);

values.description:
Our windows CI machine has been really flaky recently, so I decided to enable appveyor, since this only has one dependency, and it's available with vcpkg.

* The appveyor script is added in 71312e2 and fails because the build is broken on default.
* I fixed the build in 9686b30, by declaring the `Info` struct as visible.
* I then add the `-WX` cxx flag, so it will fail on compiler warnings, and it fails with some DLL_INTERFACE_MISSING warnings in Info.hh
* the warnings are suppressed in 268db43, and the build is clean again
values.title: Enable appveyor and fix windows build

summary.raw:

* I then add the `-WX` cxx flag, so it will fail on compiler warnings, and it fails with some DLL_INTERFACE_MISSING warnings in Info.hh
* the warnings are suppressed in 268db43, and the build is clean again

values.description:
While porting code from Gazebo-classic to Ignition, often some Gazebo 9 plugin sneakily hides inside an SDF / URDF file, happens to be on the path and we try to `dlopen` it. The problem is that this mixes 2 different versions of `ign-msgs`, which causes protobuf to throw an exception:

~~~
[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/descriptor_database.cc:57] File already exists in database: ignition/msgs/time.proto                                                         
[libprotobuf FATAL google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:1164] CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'   
  what():  CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):  
~~~

This causes the whole program to crash, and it's tough for the end user to realize what's going wrong. Ideally, we'd handle this more elegantly. Maybe something can be done on the `ign-msgs` side. But for now, I tried something here.

This try/catch block cleanly handles the situation for me, the following is printed, the library is ignored and simulation goes on:


```
Exception thrown while loading library [/home/chapulina/rmf/build/ros1/install/lib/libpayload_handler.so]
[Err] [SystemLoader.cc:75] Failed to load system plugin [libpayload_handler.so] : couldn't load library on path [/home/chapulina/rmf/build/ros1/install/lib/libpayload_handler.s
o].
```

But the catch (no pun intended) is that if I don't wrap the `dlopen` call with those sleeps, for some reason the program fails to catch protobuf's exception and crashes. I really don't understand how that would matter.

Reading answers like [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/413473/dlopen-on-library-with-static-member-that-throws-exception-in-constructor-resu) it sounds like we shouldn't be able to catch that exception in the first place, but somehow the sleeps make it work.
values.title: [WIP] Catch exception thrown during dlopen

summary.raw:
While porting code from Gazebo-classic to Ignition, often some Gazebo 9 plugin sneakily hides inside an SDF / URDF file, happens to be on the path and we try to `dlopen` it. The problem is that this mixes 2 different versions of `ign-msgs`, which causes protobuf to throw an exception:

~~~
[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/descriptor_database.cc:57] File already exists in database: ignition/msgs/time.proto                                                         
[libprotobuf FATAL google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:1164] CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'   
  what():  CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):  
~~~

This causes the whole program to crash, and it's tough for the end user to realize what's going wrong. Ideally, we'd handle this more elegantly. Maybe something can be done on the `ign-msgs` side. But for now, I tried something here.

This try/catch block cleanly handles the situation for me, the following is printed, the library is ignored and simulation goes on:


```
Exception thrown while loading library [/home/chapulina/rmf/build/ros1/install/lib/libpayload_handler.so]
[Err] [SystemLoader.cc:75] Failed to load system plugin [libpayload_handler.so] : couldn't load library on path [/home/chapulina/rmf/build/ros1/install/lib/libpayload_handler.s
o].
```

But the catch (no pun intended) is that if I don't wrap the `dlopen` call with those sleeps, for some reason the program fails to catch protobuf's exception and crashes. I really don't understand how that would matter.

Reading answers like [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/413473/dlopen-on-library-with-static-member-that-throws-exception-in-constructor-resu) it sounds like we shouldn't be able to catch that exception in the first place, but somehow the sleeps make it work.
summary.html:
While porting code from Gazebo-classic to Ignition, often some Gazebo 9 plugin sneakily hides inside an SDF / URDF file, happens to be on the path and we try to dlopen it. The problem is that this mixes 2 different versions of ign-msgs, which causes protobuf to throw an exception:

[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/descriptor_database.cc:57] File already exists in database: ignition/msgs/time.proto                                                         
[libprotobuf FATAL google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:1164] CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'   
  what():  CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):

This causes the whole program to crash, and it's tough for the end user to realize what's going wrong. Ideally, we'd handle this more elegantly. Maybe something can be done on the ign-msgs side. But for now, I tried something here.

This try/catch block cleanly handles the situation for me, the following is printed, the library is ignored and simulation goes on:

Exception thrown while loading library [/home/chapulina/rmf/build/ros1/install/lib/libpayload_handler.so]
[Err] [SystemLoader.cc:75] Failed to load system plugin [libpayload_handler.so] : couldn't load library on path [/home/chapulina/rmf/build/ros1/install/lib/libpayload_handler.s
o].

But the catch (no pun intended) is that if I don't wrap the dlopen call with those sleeps, for some reason the program fails to catch protobuf's exception and crashes. I really don't understand how that would matter.

Reading answers like this it sounds like we shouldn't be able to catch that exception in the first place, but somehow the sleeps make it work.

values.reason: We should look into a proper solution later
